original_theorem:
Let $f$ be defined on $[a,b].$ Then $f$ is continuous at $x_0$ in
$[a,b]$ if and only if $w_f(x_0)=0.$ $($Continuity at $a$ or
$b$ means continuity from the right or left, respectively.$)$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem continuousWithinAt_Icc_iff_osc_nhdsWithin_eq_zero
    {a b : ‚Ñù} {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x‚ÇÄ : ‚Ñù} (hx‚ÇÄ : x‚ÇÄ ‚àà Set.Icc a b) :
    ContinuousWithinAt f (Set.Icc a b) x‚ÇÄ ‚Üî (‚®Ö s ‚àà ùìù[Set.Icc a b] x‚ÇÄ, ediam (f '' s)) = 0 := by
```

    {a b : ‚Ñù} {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x‚ÇÄ : ‚Ñù} (hx‚ÇÄ : x‚ÇÄ ‚àà Set.Icc a b) :
    ContinuousWithinAt f (Set.Icc a b) x‚ÇÄ ‚Üî (‚®Ö s ‚àà ùìù[Set.Icc a b] x‚ÇÄ, ediam (f '' s)) = 0 := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
‚Ä¢ For $x_0 \in (a,b)$, the oscillation $w_f(x_0) = \inf_{h>0} W_f([x_0-h, x_0+h] \cap [a,b]) = 0$ [tc_3, def_3].
‚Ä¢ $\epsilon > 0$ is a positive real number.
Therefore, we conclude:
‚Ä¢ There exists an $h > 0$ such that $[x_0-h, x_0+h] \subset [a,b]$ and $W_f([x_0-h, x_0+h]) < \epsilon$ [l1].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
‚Ä¢ For a given interval $I$, $W_f(I) = \sup \{ |f(x) - f(x')| : x, x' \in I \}$ [def_2].
‚Ä¢ For some $h>0$, $W_f([x_0-h, x_0+h]) < \epsilon$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
‚Ä¢ For all $x, x'$ such that $x, x' \in [x_0-h, x_0+h]$, we have $|f(x) - f(x')| < \epsilon$ [l2].

Therefore, we conclude:
‚Ä¢ For that same $h>0$, for all $x \in [a,b]$ such that $|x - x_0| < h$, we have $|f(x) - f(x_0)| < \epsilon$ [l3].

‚Ä¢ The definition of continuity at $x_0$ [def_1].
